artefact.overview: You need a fishing vessel licence if you own or use a fishing vessel to fish at sea
artefact.licence_short_description: Fishing vessel licence if you own or use a fishing vessel to fish at sea.
artefact.licence_overview:
If you own or use a fishing vessel in the UK to fish for sea fish you will need a fishing vessel licence from the Fisheries Offices of the [Marine Management Organisation (MMO)](http://www.marinemanagement.org.uk/ "Marine Management Organisation"){:rel="external"} in England and Wales, the Environment and Rural Affairs Department of the [Scottish Government](http://home.scotland.gov.uk/home "Scottish Government"){:rel="external"} in Scotland or the [Department of Agriculture and Rural Development](http://www.dardni.gov.uk/ "Department of Agriculture and Rural Development"){:rel="external"} in Northern Ireland.

A vessel must be registered with the Registry of Shipping and Seamen (RSS) before it can be issued with a fishing vessel licence unless the vessel:

- is a salmon coble
- has an overall length of 10 metres and under and is not propelled by an engine (for example the vessel only has oars or a sail)
- has an overall length of 10 metres and under and will only be used to fish for common eels

You must also have a licence entitlement before you can license your vessel for the first time. You will acquire licence entitlement if you buy a vessel with or without its licence. You may also buy an existing separate licence entitlement.

You must apply to your local Marine Management Organisation (MMO) - using form AFL7 'Establishment or transfer of an entitlement and transfer of a licence' - to transfer the licence into your name before you can apply for a licence.

Once the licence entitlement is in your name, you need to convert it into a fishing licence. To do this you must send the following to your local MMO:

- your valid certificate of registry
- form AFL2 'Application for a fishing licence for a British registered fishing vessel'
- completed AFL7 showing you as the entitlement holder

You must send the original documents, not copies. Your local MMO office will try to process your application within five working days.

The type of licence you need depends on the size of your vessel and the category your fishing activities fall into.

Vessels are divided into two groups for licensing purposes - those that are:

- 10 metres and under in overall length
- over 10 metres in overall length

The three licence categories are:

- Category A - authorises vessels to fish for all available quota stocks and up to a restricted tonnage for combined pelagic stocks
- Category B - authorises vessels over 10 metres to fish for a restricted range of quota stocks and a restricted tonnage of combined pelagic stocks
- Category C - authorises vessels over 10 metres to fish for a range of miscellaneous stocks and a restricted tonnage of combined pelagic stocks

You do not need a fishing licence if:

- you only fish for salmon or migratory trout
- your vessel is 10 metres or less in length and you only fish for common eels
- you only fish within the 12 nautical mile limits around Jersey, Guernsey or the Isle of Man - you should contact the relevant authority for advice about their licensing requirements
- you only use your vessel for carrying anglers who are fishing for pleasure

*[RSS]: Registry of Shipping and Seamen
*[MMO]: Marine Management Organisation (MMO)
